sanskrit: श्रीभगवानुवाच | ऊर्ध्वमूलमधःशाखमश्वत्थं प्राहुरव्ययम् | छन्दांसि यस्य पर्णानि यस्तं वेद स वेदवित् ||1||
transliteration:
śhrī-bhagavān uvācha
ūrdhva-mūlam adhaḥ-śhākham aśhvatthaṁ prāhur avyayam
chhandānsi yasya parṇāni yas taṁ veda sa veda-vit
translation: The Blessed Lord said: They speak of an eternal Aśhvattha tree with its roots above and branches below. Its leaves are the Vedic hymns. One who knows this tree is the knower of the Vedas.

sanskrit: अधश्चोर्ध्वं प्रसृतास्तस्य शाखा गुणप्रवृद्धा विषयप्रवालाः | अधश्च मूलान्यनुसन्ततानि कर्मानुबन्धीनि मनुष्यलोके ||2||
transliteration:
adhaśh chordhvaṁ prasṛitās tasya śhākhā guṇa-pravṛiddhā viṣhaya-pravālāḥ
adhaśh cha mūlāny anusantatāni karmānubandhīni manuṣhya-loke
translation: Its branches extend downward and upward, nourished by the modes of nature. Sense objects are its buds. Its roots bind the soul through karma in the human world.

sanskrit: न रूपमस्येह तथोपलभ्यते नान्तो न चादिर्न च संप्रतिष्ठा | अश्वत्थमेनं सुविरूढमूलं असङ्गशस्त्रेण दृढेन छित्त्वा ||3||
transliteration:
na rūpam asyeha tathopalabhyate nānto na chādir na cha sampratiṣṭhā
aśhvattham enaṁ su-virūḍha-mūlaṁ asaṅga-śhastreṇa dṛiḍhena chhittvā
translation: Its form is not perceived here, nor its end, nor beginning, nor foundation. Having cut down this deeply rooted Aśhvattha tree with the strong axe of detachment...

sanskrit: ततः पदं तत्परिमार्गितव्यं यस्मिन्गता न निवर्तन्ति भूयः | तमेव चाद्यं पुरुषं प्रपद्ये यतः प्रवृत्तिः प्रसृता पुराणी ||4||
transliteration:
tataḥ padaṁ tat parimārgitavyaṁ yasmin gatā na nivartanti bhūyaḥ
tam eva chādyaṁ puruṣhaṁ prapadye yataḥ pravṛittiḥ prasṛitā purāṇī
translation: Then one must seek that supreme abode, from which having gone, none return. I surrender to that primeval Person, from whom all creation has emanated.

sanskrit: निर्मानमोहा जितसङ्गदोषा अध्यात्मनित्या विनिवृत्तकामाः | द्वन्द्वैर्विमुक्ताः सुखदुःखसञ्ज्ञैर्गच्छन्त्यमूढाः पदमव्ययं तत् ||5||
transliteration:
nirmāna-mohā jita-saṅga-doṣhā adhyātma-nityā vinivṛitta-kāmāḥ
dvandvair vimuktāḥ sukha-duḥkha-saṅjñair gachchhanty amūḍhāḥ padam avyayaṁ tat
translation: Free from pride and delusion, having conquered attachment, ever devoted to the Self, desireless, liberated from dualities—they attain the eternal goal.

sanskrit: न तद्भासयते सूर्यो न शशाङ्को न पावकः | यद्गत्वा न निवर्तन्ते तद्धाम परमं मम ||6||
transliteration:
na tad bhāsayate sūryo na śhaśhāṅko na pāvakaḥ
yad gatvā na nivartante tad dhāma paramaṁ mama
translation: That supreme abode of Mine is not illumined by the sun, moon, or fire. Having reached it, one never returns.

sanskrit: ममैवांशो जीवलोके जीवभूतः सनातनः | मनःषष्ठानीन्द्रियाणि प्रकृतिस्थानि कर्षति ||7||
transliteration:
mamaivāṁśho jīva-loke jīva-bhūtaḥ sanātanaḥ
manaḥ-ṣhaṣhṭhānīndriyāṇi prakṛiti-sthāni karṣhati
translation: The living beings in this world are My eternal fragments. But bound by material nature, they struggle with the six senses, including the mind.

sanskrit: शरीरं यदवाप्नोति यच्चाप्युत्क्रामतीश्वरः | गृहीत्वैतानि संयाति वायुर्गन्धानिवाशयात् ||8||
transliteration:
śharīraṁ yad avāpnoti yach chāpy utkrāmatīśhvaraḥ
gṛihītvaitāni saṁyāti vāyur gandhān ivāśhayāt
translation: When the soul acquires or leaves a body, it carries the senses and mind with it, just as the wind carries scents from their source.

sanskrit: श्रोत्रं चक्षुः स्पर्शनं च रसनं घ्राणमेव च | अधिष्ठाय मनश्चायं विषयानुपसेवते ||9||
transliteration:
śhrotraṁ chakṣhuḥ sparśhanaṁ cha rasanaṁ ghrāṇam eva cha
adhiṣhṭhāya manaśh chāyaṁ viṣhayān upasevate
translation: Presiding over the ear, eye, skin, tongue, and nose, and also the mind, the soul enjoys the sense objects.

sanskrit: उत्क्रामन्तं स्थितं वापि भुञ्जानं वा गुणान्वितम् | विमूढा नानुपश्यन्ति पश्यन्ति ज्ञानचक्षुषः ||10||
transliteration:
utkrāmantaṁ sthitaṁ vāpi bhuñjānaṁ vā guṇānvitam
vimūḍhā nānupaśhyanti paśhyanti jñāna-chakṣhuṣhaḥ
translation: The deluded do not perceive the soul as it departs, stays, or enjoys the modes. But those with the eye of knowledge see it clearly.

sanskrit: यतन्तो योगिनश्चैनं पश्यन्त्यात्मन्यवस्थितम् | यतन्तोऽप्यकृतात्मानो नैनं पश्यन्त्यचेतसः ||11||
transliteration:
yatanto yoginaśh chainaṁ paśhyanty ātmany avasthitam
yatanto ’py akṛitātmāno nainaṁ paśhyanty achetasaḥ
translation: Striving yogis perceive the soul situated within themselves. But those whose minds are impure and undisciplined, even though they strive, cannot perceive it.

sanskrit: यदादित्यगतं तेजो जगद्भासयतेऽखिलम् | यच्चन्द्रमसि यच्चाग्नौ तत्तेजो विद्धि मामकम् ||12||
transliteration:
yad āditya-gataṁ tejo jagad bhāsayate ’khilam
yach chandramasi yach chāgnau tat tejo viddhi māmakam
translation: The light that shines from the sun, which illumines the entire world, and that which is in the moon and fire—know that light to be Mine.

sanskrit: गामाविश्य च भूतानि धारयाम्यहमोजसा | पुष्णामि चौषधीः सर्वाः सोमो भूत्वा रसात्मकः ||13||
transliteration:
gām āviśhya cha bhūtāni dhārayāmy aham ojasā
puṣhṇāmi chauṣhadhīḥ sarvāḥ somo bhūtvā rasātmakaḥ
translation: Entering the earth, I sustain all beings with My energy. Becoming the moon, I nourish all plants with the juice of life.

sanskrit: अहं वैश्वानरो भूत्वा प्राणिनां देहमाश्रितः | प्राणापानसमायुक्तः पचाम्यन्नं चतुर्विधम् ||14||
transliteration:
ahaṁ vaiśhvānaro bhūtvā prāṇināṁ deham āśhritaḥ
prāṇāpāna-samāyuktaḥ pachāmy annaṁ chatur-vidham
translation: I become the fire of digestion in the bodies of all living beings. United with the incoming and outgoing breaths, I digest the four kinds of food.

sanskrit: सर्वस्य चाहं हृदि सन्निविष्टो मत्तः स्मृतिर्ज्ञानमपोहनं च | वेदैश्च सर्वैरहमेव वेद्यः वेदान्तकृद्वेदविदेव चाहम् ||15||
transliteration:
sarvasya chāhaṁ hṛidi sanniviṣhṭo mattaḥ smṛitir jñānam apohanaṁ cha
vedaiśh cha sarvair aham eva vedyaḥ vedānta-kṛid veda-vid eva chāham
translation: I am seated in the hearts of all living beings. From Me come memory, knowledge, and forgetfulness. I alone am to be known through the Vedas; I am the compiler and knower of the Vedas.

sanskrit: द्वाविमौ पुरुषौ लोके क्षरश्चाक्षर एव च | क्षरः सर्वाणि भूतानि कूटस्थोऽक्षर उच्यते ||16||
transliteration:
dvāv imau puruṣhau loke kṣharaśh chākṣhara eva cha
kṣharaḥ sarvāṇi bhūtāni kūṭa-stho ’kṣhara uchyate
translation: There are two types of beings in this world—the perishable and the imperishable. All living beings are perishable, and the soul is imperishable.

sanskrit: उत्तमः पुरुषस्त्वन्यः परमात्मेत्युदाहृतः | यो लोकत्रयमाविश्य बिभर्त्यव्यय ईश्वरः ||17||
transliteration:
uttamaḥ puruṣhas tv anyaḥ paramātmety udāhṛitaḥ
yo loka-trayam āviśhya bibharty avyaya īśhvaraḥ
translation: But there is another, the Supreme Person, called the Paramatma, who enters the three worlds and sustains them, the immutable Lord.

sanskrit: यस्मात्क्षरमतीतोऽहमक्षरादपि चोत्तमः | अतोऽस्मि लोके वेदे च प्रथितः पुरुषोत्तमः ||18||
transliteration:
yasmāt kṣharam atīto ’ham akṣharād api chottamaḥ
ato ’smi loke vede cha prathitaḥ puruṣhottamaḥ
translation: Because I transcend the perishable and am higher even than the imperishable, I am celebrated in the world and in the Vedas as the Supreme Person (Puruṣhottama).

sanskrit: यो मामेवमसम्मूढो जानाति पुरुषोत्तमम् | स सर्वविद्भजति मां सर्वभावेन भारत ||19||
transliteration:
yo mām evam asammūḍho jānāti puruṣhottamam
sa sarva-vid bhajati māṁ sarva-bhāvena bhārata
translation: One who knows Me as the Supreme Person, without delusion, worships Me with all his heart, O Bharata.

sanskrit: इति गुह्यतमं शास्त्रमिदमुक्तं मयानघ | एतद्बुद्ध्वा बुद्धिमान्स्यात्कृतकृत्यश्च भारत ||20||
transliteration:
iti guhya-tamaṁ śhāstram idam uktaṁ mayānagha
etad buddhvā buddhimān syāt kṛita-kṛityaśh cha bhārata
translation: Thus, O sinless one, I have explained to you the most confidential of all knowledge. One who understands this becomes wise and fulfills the purpose of life.
